channel.title: NYT > World > Americas
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 The New York Times Company

item.title: Carney Lifts Climate Laws for New Alberta Pipeline
item.description: Prime Minister Mark Carney reached a tentative deal with the province as part of his program to curb the country’s economic dependence on the United States.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mark Carney with Premier Danielle Smith of Alberta on Thursday in Calgary.

item.title: Why Is the U.S. Threatening Venezuela?
item.description: Venezuela doesn’t play a large role in the drug trade to the United States, so what is motivating the massive military buildup? Julian E. Barnes, who reports on intelligence and international security, discusses the issues with our senior writer Katrin Bennhold.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, Katrin Bennhold, Nikolay Nikolov, Leila Medina, Lazaro Gamio, Samuel Granados and Stephanie Swart

item.title: U.S. to Press Europe and Other Allies on Immigration, Document Says
item.description: American diplomats were told to raise U.S. concerns about “violent crimes associated with people of a migration background.”
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Hamed Aleaziz

item.title: As Trade Talks Stall, Carney Moves to Shield Canada from Trump Tariffs
item.description: Prime Minister Mark Carney announced curbs on steel imports, a new tariff and help with steel and lumber freight costs in a bid to aid Canadian industries.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Adrian Wyld/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mark Carney of Canada arriving on Parliament Hill in Ottawa on Wednesday.

item.title: Did the Giant Heads of Easter Island Once Walk?
item.description: Scholars have long debated how the massive stone figures of Rapa Nui got to where they stand today. A new study offers one possible explanation.
item.dc:creator: Franz Lidz
item.media:description: The Rapa Nui moai, the monolithic stone figures of Easter Island, were hewed from compacted ash in a quarry inside the crater of the Rano Raraku volcano between A.D. 1200 and 1700.

item.title: Venezuela’s Nobel Peace Prize Winner Pushes False Claims About Maduro
item.description: Opposition leader Maria Corina Machado faces criticism that she is exaggerating threats posed by Venezuela’s leader to justify U.S. force to overthrow him.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Maria Corina Machado has argued that Nicolás Maduro simultaneously heads two different drug trafficking organizations that threaten U.S. national security.

item.title: Penny Oleksiak, Canadian Swimmer, Faces 2-Year Ban Over Antidoping Testing Rules
item.description: Penny Oleksiak, 25, who has won seven Olympic medals, was sanctioned under antidoping rules. Her suspension ends before the 2028 Summer Olympics in Los Angeles.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:description: The Canadian swimmer Penny Oleksiak during the World Championships in 2022.

item.title: Bolsonaro To Start Serving 27-Year Prison Sentence Over Coup Plot
item.description: Brazil’s Supreme Court ordered former President Jair Bolsonaro to begin serving a prison term for conspiring to remain in power after losing the last election.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jair Bolsonaro during an interview in January.

item.title: An Eritrean Woman Seeking Asylum in Canada Was Almost Deported From the U.S.
item.description: After more than 20 years in the U.S., an Eritrean mother and nurse tried to self-deport to Canada. She found herself in a Texas detention center instead.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rahel Negassi, an Eritrean asylum seeker who worked as a nurse for over two decades in the United States while undocumented.

item.title: A Frugal Guide to St. Martin/St. Maarten
item.description: The dual-nation island of Dutch St. Maarten and French St. Martin offers lots of frugal diversions, including vivid street murals, hilly hikes and local barbecue.
item.dc:creator: Elaine Glusac and Hiroko Masuike

item.title: Trump’s Trade War Has Canadians ‘Elbows Up’ for Homegrown Wine
item.description: The trade war with the United States, bans on U.S. wine and liquor imports and a recent distributor strike in British Columbia have Canadians giving their homegrown wines another look.
item.dc:creator: Lauren McCarthy
item.media:credit: Jennilee Marigomen for The New York Times
item.media:description: The bar at the Cannon Estate Winery in Abbotsford, British Columbia. Sales there have increased by 66 percent this year.

item.title: Thomas King, Award-Winning Canadian Author, Says He Is Not Indigenous
item.description: Thomas King said he felt “ripped in half” on learning he had no Indigenous ancestry. The Canadian author has dedicated his career to writing about Indigenous people.
item.dc:creator: Qasim Nauman
item.media:description: Thomas King posing for a portrait in 2012.

item.title: ‘Find a Job,’ Ontario’s Doug Ford Tells Protester As Bill 60 Passes
item.description: During a raucous hearing, the Ontario legislature passed a bill backed by Premier Doug Ford meant to expedite housing development and the eviction of tenants who are behind on their rent.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Sean Kilpatrick/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Ontario Premier Doug Ford in Ottawa, Canada in March. On Monday, Mr, Ford, appearing exasperated after one protester taunted a guard attempting to remove the man, told him: “Go find a job, buddy.”

item.title: Bolsonaro’s Arrest Exposes Limits to Trump’s Power
item.description: President Trump tried to keep the former Brazilian president, Jair Bolsonaro, out of prison. He failed, and now he is moving on.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:description: President Trump during a bilateral meeting with President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva of Brazil in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, in October.

item.title: Russian Disinformation Comes to Mexico, Seeking to Rupture US Ties
item.description: A U.S. government cable said that Kremlin-run outlets had scaled up their efforts across Latin America, seeking to turn people against the United States and garner support for Russia.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib
item.media:description: The RT control room in Moscow in 2018. Kremlin-owned media outlets in Mexico have expanded greatly in recent years.

item.title: How a Sabotaged Ankle Monitor Ended Bolsonaro’s House Arrest
item.description: Shortly before he was expected to start serving a 27-year sentence, Brazil’s former president took a soldering iron to his tracking device.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Federal District’s Secretariat for Penitentiary Administration
item.media:description: The damaged ankle monitor of former President Jair Bolsonaro of Brazil, in a still image taken from a video released by the Federal District’s Secretariat for Penitentiary Administration.

item.title: Haitians Rejoice Over Their First World Cup Berth in 50 Years
item.description: The national team’s success in landing a World Cup slot gave Haitians around the world a momentary reprieve from their country’s deep crises.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner
item.media:description: Fans in Port-au-Prince, the capital, celebrated Haiti’s defeat of Nicaragua on Tuesday to qualify for the 2026 FIFA World Cup.

item.title: Texas Men Plotted Coup of Haitian Island to Enslave Women and Children, U.S. Says
item.description: The men, who planned to recruit homeless people for the invasion, took Haitian Creole classes and one enrolled in the U.S. Air Force to prepare for an attack by sailboat, prosecutors said.
item.dc:creator: Rylee Kirk
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: The island of Gonave as seen from Port-au-Prince, Haiti. Two Texas men were indicted in a murder and kidnapping plot that called for staging a coup of the island, federal prosecutors said.

item.title: Jair Bolsonaro Arrested in Brazil Amid Fears He Might Flee to Avoid Prison
item.description: The arrest came days before the former president was expected to be ordered to begin a 27-year prison sentence for staging a failed coup.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Jair Bolsonaro during his house arrest in Brasília on Friday. The former president was arrested the next morning.

item.title: Cannon and Other Artifacts Are Recovered From San José Shipwreck
item.description: Colombian scientists also retrieved three coins and a porcelain cup from the San José, which treasure hunters have come to call the Holy Grail of shipwrecks.
item.dc:creator: Rylee Kirk
item.media:description: A photograph released by the Colombian government shows President Gustavo Petro examining a cannon that was recovered from the wreckage of the San José, a Spanish galleon that sank in 1708.

item.title: Are Fighter Jets Canada’s ‘Bargaining Chip’ in Trade Talks?
item.description: Canada began a review of its fighter jet deal with the United States after President Trump imposed tariffs. Now, Sweden is back with a sales pitch for its own jets.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Spencer Colby/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mark Carney and King Carl XVI Gustaf of Sweden at a state dinner in Ottawa this week. Sweden wants to sell fighter jets manufactured by Saab, a Swedish company, to Canada.

item.title: A Socialist Priest Embraces Venezuela’s Maduro, an Autocratic Leader
item.description: The Rev. Numa Molina, a Jesuit priest, has championed the poor for decades. Now, he is a power broker and a confidant of Venezuela’s embattled president, Nicolás Maduro.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Adriana Loureiro Fernandez
item.media:description: People line up to take photos with Father Numa Molina after a Mass in Marizapa, Venezuela.

item.title: 3 Children Are Injured in Grizzly Bear Attack in British Columbia
item.description: The children were among 11 people who were hurt when a grizzly attacked a school group in a remote part of British Columbia, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: Aimee Ortiz and Hannah Ziegler
item.media:credit: Jonathan Hayward/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Grizzly bears in Tweedsmuir Provincial Park near Bella Coola, British Columbia.

item.title: Satellite Data Reveals How the U.S. Navy Is Deployed Near Venezuela
item.description: The Times identified nearly 100 locations traversed by naval vessels across a two-and-a-half-month period to determine what the military pressure campaign against Venezuela looks like at sea.
item.dc:creator: Riley Mellen
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The guided-missile destroyer Gravely leaving a port in Trinidad and Tobago in late October. It is among several U.S. Navy vessels sailing near the coast of Venezuela.
